etymology.description: pictogram: variant form of 水 depicting flowing water.
etymology.interpretation: An early pictorial form of water, showing flowing lines or droplets. Later standardization favored 水, while this variant survives in historical texts and certain calligraphic/component contexts.

examples.chinese: 古籍里常见“氺”字，意思是水(古籍裡常見「氺」字，意思是水)。
examples.pinyin: Gǔjí lǐ chángjiàn “shuǐ” zì, yìsi shì shuǐ.
examples.english: In ancient books, the form “氺” is common and means water.

examples.chinese: 在篆书和隶书中，“氺”常用作“水”的异体(在篆書和隸書中，「氺」常用作「水」的異體)。
examples.pinyin: Zài zhuànshū hé lìshū zhōng, “shuǐ” cháng yòngzuò “shuǐ” de yìtǐ.
examples.english: In seal and clerical scripts, “氺” is often used as a variant of “水.”

examples.chinese: 这个字今天不常用，但在姓氏或地名的古写中仍可见(這個字今天不常用，但在姓氏或地名的古寫中仍可見)。
examples.pinyin: Zhège zì jīntiān bù chángyòng, dàn zài xìngshì huò dìmíng de gǔxiě zhōng réng kějiàn.
examples.english: This character is not commonly used today, but it can still be seen in archaic forms of surnames or place names.
